status_details: Gov. Mike Dunleavy, a Republican, eased restrictions on several kinds of businesses starting April 24. Alaska became one of the first states to make a nearly complete reopening, with all businesses allowed to open at full capacity on May 22. Cases increased over summer, however, and in August Mr. Dunleavy implemented strict requirements for travelers entering the state.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, etc.
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Theaters; Bowling alleys; Museums
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools

status_details: Gov. Kay Ivey, a Republican, ordered residents to stay home for much of April and began reopening businesses starting in May. In August, Ms. Ivey extended the state’s “Safer at Home” status and implemented a mask requirement until October 2.
opened_personal_care: Salons
opened_entertainment: Entertainment venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Asa Hutchinson, a Republican, never implemented a statewide stay-at-home order, instead opting to close high-contact businesses like gyms and personal care services. The state began reopening many of these in early May. Arkansas saw a steep increases in coronavirus cases in the weeks that followed, and Mr. Hutchinson implemented a mask mandate effective July 20.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, etc.
opened_entertainment: Theaters, stadiums, museums, bowling alleys; Casinos; Large venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms; Pools

status_details: After Gov. Doug Ducey’s stay-at-home order expired May 15, Arizona saw cases soar. In late June, Mr. Ducey, a Republican, announced that the state would “pause” operations of bars, gyms, movie theaters, waterparks and tubing rentals to contain the virus’s spread, sparking lawsuits from some business owners. A court ruled that the state had to give businesses the opportunity to reopen safely, prompting Mr. Ducey to release guidelines on August 10 for “paused businesses” to follow in order to reopen.
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, salons, etc.
opened_entertainment: Casinos
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools, spas

status_details: Gov. Gavin Newsom, a Democrat, emphasized caution as he allowed counties to reopen sectors in May and June. As cases rose in the summer, Mr. Newsom backtracked, ordering statewide closures of bars and indoor activities in many sectors including dining and entertainment. In late August, the state introduced a new plan for reopening and closing counties based on risk level, which allowed indoor retail and hair salons to open even in the counties where the virus was most widespread.
opened_industries: Manufacturing; Warehouses; Offices in some counties; Movie, TV and music production
closed_entertainment: Movie theaters; Museums, galleries, and aquariums; Arcades and bowling alleys
opened_houses_of_worship: Houses of worship in some counties
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Nail salons, cosmetology services, tattoo parlors, piercing shops in some counties; Hair salons and barbershops
opened_entertainment: Casinos in some areas; Zoos in some counties
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms in some counties

status_details: Gov. Jared Polis was one of the first Democratic governors to begin reopening his state, letting Colorado’s stay-at-home order expire on April 26. Businesses reopened throughout May and June, but in response to continuing outbreaks in neighboring states, in July, Mr. Polis extended the state’s “Safer at Home” phase and closed bars. He is allowing some regions to reopen bars and loosen restrictions.
opened_personal_care: Salons and personal services
opened_entertainment: Museums, indoor events; Fairs, rodeos, concerts, outdoor events; Libraries
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining; Bars in some counties
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Pools, playgrounds; Gyms

status_details: Connecticut was one of the last states to begin reopening, on May 20. Gov. Ned Lamont, a Democrat, moved up a second phase of reopening in June after a favorable downward trend in case numbers. After postponing plans to enter Phase 3 over the summer, Mr. Lamont announced the state would move forward in its reopening in October.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons; Tattoo parlors, spas
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos; Casinos; Movie theaters; Libraries; Amusement parks, bowling alleys
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Gyms; State campgrounds

status_details: Washington, D.C., was under one of the nation’s strictest lockdowns until reopening on May 29. On June 22,  Mayor Muriel Bowser, a Democrat, opened a second round of businesses. On July 24, she signed an order requiring masks.
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons; Nail salons, waxing salons, spas
opened_entertainment: Museums, libraries
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Dog parks, golf courses, tennis courts, parks; Gyms; Pools

status_details: Gov. John Carney, a Democrat, has overseen one of the slower reopenings, beginning June 1 with a limited number of businesses. After an increase in cases, Mr. Carney decided to delay the start of Phase 3, which was scheduled for the end of June.
opened_personal_care: Barber shops, hair salons, tanning salons; Nail salons, tattoo parlors, massage therapy
opened_entertainment: Museums, libraries, galleries, live performances; Casinos
opened_food_and_drink: Farmers markets; Restaurants; Bars in some areas
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Pools; Gyms; Campgrounds

status_details: After reopenings in May and June led to outbreaks throughout summer, Gov. Ron DeSantis, a Republican, began to slow reopening, effectively shuttering bars in late June. By the end of summer, however, Mr. DeSantis moved to more broadly reopen the state. After reopening bars statewide in mid-September, on Sept. 25 Mr. DeSantis said restaurants could reopen and "operate at a minimum of 50 percent regardless of local rule."
opened_personal_care: Salons; Tattoo parlors, massage therapy, tanning salons, acupuncture
opened_entertainment: Sporting venues without spectators; Museums, libraries; Movie theaters, concert halls, bowling alleys
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches, trails; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Brian Kemp, a Republican, went toe-to-toe with the White House and local mayors over his decision to reopen large parts of Georgia’s economy ahead of other states. Mr. Kemp has continued steadily with reopening plans while case counts have trended upward, and he has firmly opposed recommendations for a statewide mask mandate. In mid-August, however, he amended an executive order to allow local areas to implement mask requirements.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, etc.
opened_entertainment: Bowling alleys; Theaters, private social clubs; Large venues; Bars, nightclubs
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms

status_details: Gov. David Ige, a Democrat, started the state’s reopening process in early May, when there were only a few new cases reported each day. Since then, each island has set its own timeline for reopening, and in late August, Oahu returned to a nearly full shutdown. Four weeks later, Mr. Ige approved a plan for the island, which is home to the capital Honolulu, to reopen most businesses at limited capacity.
opened_industries: Construction in some areas; Offices in some areas
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Tattoo parlors in some areas; Salons and barbershops; Nail salons
opened_entertainment: Theaters; Arcades in some areas; Bowling alleys
opened_food_and_drink: Bars in some areas; Restaurant dining
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks in some areas; Campgrounds in some areas; Gyms; Pools and waterparks; Beaches and parks

status_details: Gov. Kim Reynolds, a Republican, ordered a number of businesses to close in March, but did not issue a stay-at-home order. Ms. Reynolds began loosening restrictions on May 1, and capacity limits on businesses were lifted in June. In late August, Reynolds ordered bars in six counties to shutdown, citing increasing positivity rates among young adults. Ms. Reynolds allowed bars in four of the six counties to reopen nearly three weeks later.
opened_personal_care: Medical spas, tanning salons; Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Movie theaters; Museums, zoos, aquariums; Casinos; Outdoor venues; Bowling alleys, amusement parks; Indoor venues
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining; Bars in some counties
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms; Pools; Playgrounds, skating rinks, skate parks

status_details: Gov. Brad Little, a Republican, began his state’s four-stage reopening process on May 1. Idaho moved through the first three stages of reopening swiftly, but as cases surged, Mr. Little delayed a full reopening planned for June 26. The state has remained paused in its final stage for several months, re-evaluating every two weeks.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Nightclubs; Large venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools and water parks

status_details: Gov. J.B. Pritzker, a Democrat, faced political pushback for his cautious reopening strategy, but while the state remained closed, cases trended downward. On June 26, the state moved into its fourth and final stage of reopening, but as transmission increased over the summer Mr. Pritzker introduced a "mitigation" plan for areas with increasing positive test rates. In August and September, Mr. Pritzker implemented these measures by closing indoor bars and restaurants in regions that saw an uptick in transmission.
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming; Hair salons, barber shops, nail salons, spas, waxing centers, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos; Theaters; Casinos in some areas
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining in some areas; Bars in some areas
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; limited fishing, boating, golf courses; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Eric Holcomb, a Republican, eased restrictions and allowed some reopenings beginning in early May. In July, citing an increase in cases, Mr. Holcomb paused progress toward the final stage of reopening and required face masks in most public settings. Mr. Holcomb allowed the state to progress to Phase 5, the final stage of reopening, in late September.
opened_personal_care: Spas, salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Libraries; Museums, zoos and aquariums; Venues; Movie theaters; Bowling alleys; Conventions, fairs, parades and similar events
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools, tennis and basketball courts; Campgrounds; Amusement parks, water parks

status_details: After reopening began May 4, Gov. Laura Kelly, a Democrat, faced backlash from Republicans in the state legislature who wanted the process to move more quickly. She vetoed a measure seeking to curb her emergency powers, and allowed reopenings at the discretion of individual counties. Ms. Kelly ordered Kansans to wear masks in public beginning July 3.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Theaters, museums and bowling alleys; Casinos; Nightclubs
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Community centers, sports facilities; Pools

status_details: Gov. Andy Beshear, a Democrat, reopened businesses under new guidelines beginning in early May, then ordered residents to wear masks in public soon after the state had reached the end of its initial reopening timeline. As case numbers continued to climb, Mr. Beshear ordered bars to close again starting July 28 and restaurants to reduce indoor dining capacity. Mr. Beshear lifted those restrictions and allowed bars to reopen two weeks later.
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming and boarding; Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Bowling alleys; Museums, aquariums, libraries, outdoor attractions; Venues and events spaces
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Aquatic centers; Campgrounds; Public pools

status_details: Gov. John Bel Edwards, a Democrat, allowed the state’s stay-at-home order to lift and an array of businesses to reopen starting May 15. In June, citing an increase in cases, Mr. Edwards said the state would remain in Phase 2 for several more weeks. As cases continued to climb, Mr. Edwards ordered bars to close again and required the use of masks in public. In September, Mr. Edwards announced that the state would enter a modified Phase 3, which allowed bars to reopen in areas with low positivity rates.
closed_outdoor_and_recreation: Amusement parks, water parks and theme parks; Concert and music halls
opened_personal_care: Salons and barbershops; Spas, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Certain museums, zoos and aquariums; Casinos; Event centers
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining; Bars in some parishes
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; State parks; Pools; Bowling alleys, skating rinks

status_details: Gov. Charlie Baker, a Republican, announced a phased reopening beginning in May. The state entered the first step of Phase 3 in early July. One month later, Mr. Baker announced that the state would indefinitely delay any further progression due to an increase in cases. Mr. Baker also announced he would reduce outdoor gathering limits to 50 people. Mr. Baker began to relax some restrictions in September, allowing arcades to reopen and relaxing restrictions on restaurants.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Pet grooming; Nail salons, massage parlors, tanning salons
opened_entertainment: Bowling alleys; Museums, aquariums; Theaters and performance venues; Movie theaters; Casinos; Arcades
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; Beaches, parks, fishing, hunting and boating; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Larry Hogan, a Republican who has called for an aggressive response to the virus, allowed some businesses to open with social distancing requirements starting May 15, but encouraged the adoption of more restrictive local guidelines as needed. In late July, Mr. Hogan said the state was “in a holding pattern” and “not ready to reopen further.” He later expanded a statewide mask order, requiring face coverings in nearly all public settings. In early September, Mr. Hogan announced that the state would be moving to the third and final phase of reopening, which allows all businesses to reopen, including movie theaters and live entertainment venues.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, massage parlors, tanning salons, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Casinos; Movie theaters; Live entertainment venues
opened_food_and_drink: Outdoor service at breweries, wineries, and distilleries; Restaurants; Bars
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, outdoor shooting ranges, marinas, campgrounds; Beaches; Outdoor pools and day camps; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Janet Mills, a Democrat, allowed some businesses to begin reopening statewide in May and allowed additional, accelerated reopenings in counties with few coronavirus cases. More businesses were allowed to reopen statewide in June, but further reopenings, including of bars, have been delayed.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, pet groomers; Nail salons and tattoo parlors; Spas and massage parlors
opened_entertainment: Amusement parks, water parks; Bowling alleys and arcades; Movie theaters; Performing arts venues; Casinos
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurants; Bars open for outdoor service
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks, boating, golf courses; Remote campgrounds, hunting and fishing; Private campgrounds, RV parks; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, a Democrat, took a regional approach to reopening before lifting Michigan’s stay-at-home order on June 1. Ms. Whitmer has since paused further reopenings, and on July 1, she ordered bars in most of the state to close again for indoor service. She later mandated the use of masks in most public settings. In late July, citing a resurgence in cases connected to social gatherings, Ms. Whitmer limited indoor gatherings to 10 people and ordered bars to close for indoor service statewide. Ms. Whitmer allowed gyms to reopen in September, and later announced she would allow certain indoor facilities including movie theaters, bowling alleys and performance venues to reopen in early October.
opened_industries: Construction, real estate; Manufacturing, including auto companies; Offices
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers; Hair salons, barbershops, nail salons, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Arcades, theaters, and convention centers in some regions; Casinos
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining; Bars for outdoor service
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, marinas; Pools; Gyms; Bowling alleys for organized sports; Skating rinks for organized sports

status_details: Gov. Tim Walz, a Democrat, first allowed employees in certain agriculture, industrial and office settings to return to work in late April. More businesses were allowed to open after his stay-at-home order expired in May. Mr. Walz later ordered the use of face masks in most public settings beginning July 25.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Theaters and concert halls; Bowling alleys, arcades and museums
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, reopened all businesses in early May, with social distancing requirements, and lifted all restrictions on June 16. In September, Mr. Parson tested positive for the coronavirus.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, music venues, etc.; Casinos
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Campgrounds

status_details: Gov. Tate Reeves, a Republican, let the state’s stay-at-home order expire April 27 and reopened retail stores, with some limits. All businesses were allowed to open in June, but in July Mr. Reeves said the state would pause a full reopening. As case numbers continued to climb, he tightened restrictions on social gatherings and bars statewide, and later issued a mask mandate. School reopenings were delayed for higher grades in certain counties. In September, Mr. Reeves allowed restaurants, retail stores and gyms to increase capacity to 75 percent.
opened_personal_care: Salons and barbershops; Tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Casinos; Movie theaters; Libraries, museums
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Steve Bullock, a Democrat, allowed reopening in phases, beginning in late April. All businesses could reopen June 1, provided they followed certain guidelines. In July, citing rising case counts, Mr. Bullock ordered Montanans in certain counties to wear masks in many public settings. He later amended this order to include schools.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, massage parlors
opened_entertainment: Museums, movie theaters; Concert venues; Bowling alleys; Casinos
opened_food_and_drink: Restaurant dining, bars, breweries and distilleries
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms

status_details: Gov. Roy Cooper, a Democrat, allowed a variety of businesses to reopen in May. In late June, with case counts trending upward, Mr. Cooper paused North Carolina’s reopening plan and required residents to wear face coverings in public. In early September, Mr. Cooper introduced "Phase 2.5," which allows for the reopening of gyms, bowling alleys, museums and aquariums.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Museums and aquariums; Bowling alleys and skating rinks
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools; Playgrounds; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Doug Burgum, a Republican, never issued a stay-at-home order, and allowed a variety of businesses to reopen starting May 1. In September, Mr. Burgum reclassified eight counties from the "low risk" category into the "moderate risk" category under the state's guidance, which recommends—but does not require—reducing capacity limits in businesses. Mr. Burgum also reclassified 13 counties into the "new normal" phase, the lowest risk level of the state's guidance.
opened_personal_care: Salons, tattoo parlors, massage therapy, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters; Music and entertainment venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Sports venues

status_details: Gov. Pete Ricketts, a Republican, never issued a stay-at-home order but he put in place several restrictions on businesses, which he began to lift on a regional basis starting in early May. Most of the state will be in Phase 4, which removes all restrictions on a number of businesses, beginning Sept. 14.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.
opened_entertainment: Zoos, movie theaters, libraries and venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Pools; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Chris Sununu, a Republican, gradually reopened sectors starting in mid-May. On June 15, he allowed his stay-at-home order to expire and reopened businesses on a rolling basis. The final round of businesses reopened, with capacity limits and social distancing guidance, on June 29.
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons, etc.; Nail salons; Tanning salons; Tattoo shops; Acupuncturists and massage therapists
opened_entertainment: Libraries, museums, art galleries; Bowling alleys and entertainment centers; Movie theaters; Amusement parks; Live performances
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; Outdoor attractions; Beaches; Gyms; Pools

status_details: Gov. Phil Murphy, a Democrat, was one of the last governors to lift a stay-at-home order, on June 9. New Jersey cautiously reopened businesses over the course of May and June, and rolling reopenings were set to continue into July. After putting a pause on plans in July, Mr. Murphy announced the reopening of gyms, indoor entertainment, and indoor dining in early September.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, tattoo parlors, spas, massage therapy, tanning salons

status_details: Gov. Michelle Lujan Grisham, a Democrat, allowed some sectors to reopen May 16. As cases rose, Ms. Grisham announced she would delay the next phase of reopening indefinitely, and later ordered restaurants to restrict indoor dining. In late August, Ms. Grisham announced that she would allow indoor dining to resume at 25 percent capacity, along with permitting some museums to reopen and increasing the gathering limit to 10 people.
opened_personal_care: Pet grooming and boarding, veterinary services; Hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, massage parlors, nail salons
opened_entertainment: Certain museums

opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Golf courses, boating; Gyms, pools

status_details: Gov. Steve Sisolak, a Democrat, kept pace with other states and reopened businesses throughout May. Casinos and gaming were allowed to resume operations on June 4. Over summer, Mr. Sisolak slowed the state's reopening, closing bars in some counties where the virus was resurging, but in mid-September allowed bars to reopen again statewide.
opened_personal_care: Barbershops, hair salons and nail salons; Massage therapy; Tattoo and piercing shops
opened_entertainment: Museums, art galleries, zoos and aquariums; Movie theaters, bowling alleys; Gaming

status_details: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, a Democrat, announced limited and phased reopenings by region starting May 15. New York City, the hardest-hit region in the state, became the last to enter Phase 4 of reopening on July 20. But unlike in other regions, indoor dining will remain prohibited in New York City until the end of September.
opened_industries: Construction, manufacturing; Offices; Film and TV production
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Tattoo parlors, massage parlors, nail salons

status_details: Gov. Mike DeWine, a Republican, lifted a stay-at-home order on May 1 and allowed businesses to reopen in phases, starting with retail stores, salons and restaurants. In July, Mr. DeWine asked several counties to limit activities and gatherings of any size, though he did not order any closures. Starting July 23, the use of face masks became mandatory statewide in both indoor and outdoor public spaces. Mr. DeWine allowed school sports and professional sports to resume starting August 21, but limited the spectator attendance to 15 percent.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, museums, art galleries; Casinos, racinos, amusement parks, water parks

status_details: Gov. Kevin Stitt, a Republican, implemented a three-phase approach to reopening businesses starting April 24. Phase 3 began in June, when all restrictions were lifted on businesses and group gatherings provided people “consider social distancing.”
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, spas, pet groomers, etc.; Tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, sports venues, museums; Nightclubs
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Zoos; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Kate Brown, a Democrat, started a three-phase regional reopening on May 15, but said Phase 3 would not come until September at the earliest. Masks are required in both indoor and outdoor spaces, and indoor gatherings of more than 10 people are prohibited. In late July, due to an increase in COVID-19 cases, Umatilla County moved back to stay at home status, while Morrow and Malheur counties moved to Phase 1. On September 18, Umatilla and Morrow returned to Phase 2.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, bowling alleys in most counties
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Some state parks; Pools in most counties; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, took a county-by-county approach to shutting down and took a similar approach to reopening, allowing counties to open in phases. By July 3, all of the state was in the last phase of reopening, but wearing a mask is now required in all public places. Starting September 21, indoor dinning will be increased to 50 percent capacity. On September 14, a judge struck down business closures as well as indoor and outdoor gathering limitations imposed by the governor. Mr. Wolf said he would appeal.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, spas
opened_entertainment: Casinos, theaters
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses, marinas, private campgrounds; Beaches; State parks; Public pools; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Wanda Vázquez announced a curfew and closed non-essential businesses in March. Restaurants and retail stores were allowed to reopen in late May, but by mid-July she ordered the re-closure of bars, movie theaters, casinos and gyms. Ms. Vázquez also announced a 24-hour lockdown on Sundays beginning August 22, along with reduced capacity in restaurants, malls and houses of worship. Beginning September 12, most businesses will be allowed to reopen, with capacity limits, and the Sunday lockdown will be lifted. A mandatory 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew will remain in place through October 2.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops; Pet grooming
opened_entertainment: Museums; Outdoor concerts and other open venues; Movie theaters
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Beaches; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Gina Raimondo, a Democrat, announced a three-phase reopening plan starting with retail stores after her stay-at-home order lifted on May 8. Rhode Island entered its second phase of reopening in June, with restaurants, gyms, salons and beaches allowed to open. The third phase began June 30 and was extended through the end of September, with indoor gatherings limited to 15 people.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops; Nail salons, massage parlors, tattoo shops
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Beaches; Gyms; Casinos; Campgrounds

status_details: Gov. Henry McMaster, a Republican, was among the last to issue a stay-at-home order and among the first to begin opening up his state, starting April 20 with retail stores. Mr. McMaster will allow movie theaters, concerts, race tracks or nightclubs to reopen starting August 3, but with a 50 percent capacity limit and a mask requirement. Restaurants will be required to follow the same safety guidelines.

date_details: Updated guidance for businesses and residents on April 28.
status_details: Gov. Kristi Noem, a Republican, refused to issue a stay-at-home order — despite requests from local officials — and did not close businesses in the state, though she ordered them to follow C.D.C. guidelines. She invited workers and business owners frustrated by lockdowns in other states to visit South Dakota.

status_details: Gov. Bill Lee, a Republican, announced reopening plans for 89 of 95 Tennessee counties starting April 27. The remaining counties were to follow individual reopening plans.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, etc.
opened_entertainment: Theaters, museums, amusement parks
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks; Gyms

status_details: Gov. Greg Abbott allowed his stay-at-home order to lapse on April 30, a move that gave Texas one of the shortest such orders in the country. A surge in cases in late June caused Mr. Abbott to order bars to close and restaurants to reduce capacity, among the first reopening reversals in the country. Starting July 3, he once again encouraged Texans to stay home and required face coverings in public places in counties with more than 20 cases. Starting September 21, restaurants, retail stores, gyms, libraries and museums can increase capacity to 75%.

status_details: Gov. Gary R. Herbert, a Republican, started to reopen Utah by region on May 1. Now, just one county remains at “moderate risk,” and restaurants, gyms and salons are open everywhere.
opened_personal_care: Salons, personal care businesses
opened_entertainment: Movie theatres, museums, libraries, concerts
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; Pools

status_details: Gov. Ralph Northam, a Democrat, started reopening much of the state on May 15, and all counties moved into Phase 3 on July 1. Starting July 31, Mr. Northam will implement restrictions on restaurants and bars in some counties and public gatherings will be limited.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, etc.
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos, aquariums, outdoor concerts
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Campgrounds; Beaches; Gyms; Pools

status_details: Gov. Phil Scott, a Republican, allowed small changes, such as the opening of farmers’ markets, before a broader reopening beginning with retail stores on May 18. Other businesses, such as gyms and restaurants, reopened in June. Face masks are required in both indoor and outdoor public spaces.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons and barbershops; Nail salons, spas, tattoo parlors
opened_entertainment: Museums, theaters, libraries
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks, golf courses, trails, etc.; Campgrounds; Gyms, fitness centers

status_details: While every county has now moved into some phase of reopening, Gov. Jay Inslee, a Democrat, said in late July that he would pause further reopenings and expanded an order to use face coverings in all public spaces. Restaurants, gyms and movie theaters must reduce capacity in some counties. On August 20, Mr. Inslee allowed museums and bowling alleys to operate in some counties, and as of September 11, gyms in all counties can reopen.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, etc.; Pet grooming
opened_entertainment: Casinos; Museums in some counties; Bowling alleys  in some counties
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: State parks, fishing, hunting, golf courses; Gyms

status_details: The state Supreme Court struck down Gov. Tony Evers's stay-at-home order on May 13, effectively lifting statewide restrictions on businesses in Wisconsin. Mr. Evers, a Democrat in a highly contested battleground state, had already announced plans for a gradual reopening but warned the ruling would cause “chaos.” Some counties have since placed their own restrictions on businesses. Mr. Evers mandated the use of face coverings in all public indoor places starting August 1.
opened_personal_care: Pet groomers for curbside dropoff; Hair salons, spas, barbershops
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Golf courses; State parks; Gyms

status_details: West Virginia’s stay-at-home order was in place for a little more than a month. Gov. Jim Justice, a Republican, lifted restrictions on certain businesses on May 4, with new reopenings each following week. Starting July 7, face coverings are required where social distance can’t be maintained. The governor limited social gatherings to 25 people, ordered the closure of fairs, festivals and concerts statewide. Mr. Justice ordered the closure of bars in Monongalia County.
opened_personal_care: Salons, barbershops, pet groomers; Tanning salons; Massage parlors and spas
opened_entertainment: Museums, zoos; Bowling alleys, pool halls, roller rinks; Casinos; Movie theaters; Amusement parks, fairs, festivals
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms, recreation centers; State parks, campgrounds; Pools

status_details: Gov. Mark Gordon, a Republican, did not order Wyoming residents to stay home, and he began lifting restrictions on businesses on May 1. As of August 16, outdoor venues were allowed to hold gatherings of up to 1,000 people, and in September, indoor close-contact sports resumed. The governor recently extended safety measures on restaurants, bars, gyms and schools through September 30.
opened_personal_care: Hair salons, barbershops, tattoo parlors, massage therapy, etc.
opened_entertainment: Movie theaters, entertaiment venues
opened_outdoor_and_recreation: Gyms; State parks
